sp.p: I will do my endeavour to see them all; for I will go to each bridal house.

sp.speaker: 1 gentleman
sp.p: How will you do so, being all married on a day?

sp.speaker: 2 gentleman
sp.p: Why I will bid good-morrow to the one, and I will go to church with another, and dine with the third, and dance the afternoon with the fourth, and see the fifth a-bed .

sp.speaker: 1 gentleman
sp.p: That you may do.

div.head: Scene 30.
div.stage: Enter mistress troublesome, and her maid.

sp.speaker: Mistress troubles.
sp.p: Lord there are so many weddings to be tomorrow, as I know not which to go to! Besides, I shall displease those I go not to, being invited to them all.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: If you would displease neither of them, you must feign yourself sick, and go to none of them.

sp.speaker: Mistress troubles.
sp.p: None of them, say you? that would be a cause to make me die; for I would not but be a guest to one of them for any thing could be given me: but I am resolved to go to the lady conversation and sir experienced traveller's wedding, for there there will be the most company, and it is company that I love better than the wedding-cheer; for much company is a feast to me.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Truly mistress, I wonder you should delight in company, you being in years.

sp.speaker: Mistress troubles.
sp.p: Out you naughty wench, do you say I am old?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: No indeed, I did not name old.

sp.speaker: Mistress troubles.
sp.p: Then let me tell you, that those women that are in years, seek company to divulge their wit, as youth to divulge their beauty; and we aged wits may chance to catch a lover from a young beauty: but I should applaud my own wit, if it could contrive to bring each bride and bridegroom into one assembly, making Hymen's monarchy a republic, where all should be in common.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: So mistress you would prove a traitor to Hymen, which is a bawd.

sp.speaker: Mistress troubles.
sp.p: Faith I will turn you away for your boldness.

div.stage: O mistress gossip you are welcome, what news!

sp.speaker: Mistress gossip.
sp.p: I am come to tell you, that the five bridals meet with their guests and good cheer at the city-hall, and make their several companies joining as one, as one body, and there will be such revelling, as the like was never before.

sp.speaker: Mistress troubles.
sp.p: Juno be thanked, and Venus be praised for it; for I was much perplexed concerning their divisions, till you came and brought me this good news of their corporation.

div.head: Scene 31.
div.stage: Enter the lord title, and the lady virtue as his bride, both of them richly attired, and old humanity following them.

sp.speaker: Lord title.
sp.p: Come old humanity, and be our father, to join and give us in the church; and then when we are married, we will live a country-life, I as a shepherd, and this lady as my fair shepherdess.

div.head: Scene 32.
div.stage: Enter the lady Ward as a bride, and her nurse nurse careful.

sp.speaker: Nurse careful.
sp.p: My dear child, you appear as a sweet budding rose this morning.

sp.speaker: Lady ward.
sp.p: Roses are beset with thorns, nurse, I hope I am not so.

sp.speaker: Nurse Caref.
sp.p: By'r lady your husband may prove a thorn, if he be not a good man, and a kind husband; but o my heart doth ache.

sp.speaker: Lady ward.
sp.p: Wherefore doth it ache?

div.stage: Enter lord courtship as a bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Lord courts.
sp.p: Come sweet, are you ready? for it is time to go to church, it is almost twelve o'clock .

sp.speaker: Lady ward.
sp.p: I am ready, but my nurse doth affright me, by telling me her heart doth ache, as if she did foreknow by her experienced age some ill fortune towards me, or that I shall be unhappy in my marriage.

sp.speaker: Lord courts.
sp.p: Her heart doth not ache for you, but for herself, because she cannot be a young fair bride, as you are, as being passed her youth; so that her heart doth ache out of a sad remembrance of herself, not for a present, or a future cause for you.

sp.speaker: Nurse Caref.
sp.p: Well, well, I was young indeed, and a comely bride when I was married, though I say it, and had a loving bridegroom, heaven rest his soul.

div.head: Scene 33.
div.stage: Enter the lady visitant as a bride, to the lady conplation, another bride.

sp.speaker: Lady Visit.
sp.p: Come, I have brought all my bridal guests hither to join with yours, for we will go to church together: wherefore prithee come away, our bridegrooms and our guests stay for you.

sp.speaker: Lady contempl
sp.p: I will go to them by and by.

sp.speaker: Lady Visit.
sp.p: Why, I hope you do not stay to muse upon phantasms, saith marriage will banish them out of your head, you must now employ your time with realities.

sp.speaker: Lady contempl
sp.p: If I thought marriage would destroy or disturb my contemplations, I would not marry, although my wedding-guests were come, and my wedding-dinner ready dressed, and my wedding-clothes on; nay, were I at the holy altar, I would return back.

sp.speaker: Lady Visit.
sp.p: That would be such an action, as all the kingdom would say you were mad.

sp.speaker: Lady contemplation
sp.p: I had rather all the world should not only say I were mad, but think me so, rather than myself to be unhappy.

sp.speaker: Lady Visit.
sp.p: Can want of contemplation make you unhappy?

sp.speaker: Lady contemplation
sp.p: Yes, as unhappy as a body can be without a soul; for contemplation is the life of the soul, and who can be happy that hath a dead soul?

sp.speaker: Lady Visit.
sp.p: By my troth I had rather be dead, than have such a dull life.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam, the bridegroom is coming hither.

sp.speaker: Lady contempl
sp.p: I will prevent him, and meet him.

sp.speaker: 1 gentlem.
sp.p: Come away, come away, they'll be all married before we shall get to church.

sp.speaker: 2 gentleman
sp.p: There will be enough witnesses, we may well be spared; but so I share of the feast, I care not whether they be married or not.

sp.speaker: 1 gentleman
sp.p: The truth is, the benefit to us will be only in eating of their meat, and drinking of their wine.

sp.speaker: 2 gentleman
sp.p: And I mean to be drunk, but not for joy of their marriages, but for pleasure of my gusto.

div.head: Scene 35.
div.stage: Enter the five couples, and all the bridal guests: the bridegrooms and the bride's dance, and the while the bridal torches are held in their hands: then a ` poet speaks thus to them.

sp.speaker: Speaker.
sp.l: What lines of light do from those torches spin,
Which winds about those ladies' whiter skin?
But from their eyes more splend'rous beams do run,
As bright as those that issue from the sun.
Wherein the lesser lights wax dull and dim,
Or like as minnows in an ocean swim.

sp.speaker: Mall mean-bred.
sp.p: By your good leave gentlefolks,The lord marquess writ this sceneI am come here to complain of this hog-rubber sir golden riches, who did tempt me with gold till he had his desire, you know all what it is, and I like an honest woman, as it were, kept my word, and performed truly as any woman could do: speak, canst thou detect me either in word or deed? and like a false and covetous wretch as thou art, performed nothing with me as thou shouldst have done, I am sure of that: is't not a truth? speak coverous wretch, speak.

sp.speaker: Sir gold. Rich.
sp.p: Why, what did I promise you?

sp.speaker: Mall mean-bred.
sp.p: Why thou didst promise me an hundred pounds in gold, showed it me, and then took it away again; nay further, thou saidst I should be a lady, and have a great parimanus coach gilt, with neighing horses, and a coachman, with a postilion to ride afore: nay, nay, I remember well enough what you said, you talked of Gessimond, pomatum, and Roman gunpowder for my hair, and fine gowns and stockings, and fine laced silk garters, and roses shining like stars, God bless us!

sp.speaker: Sir gold. Rich.
sp.p: Did I, did I?

sp.speaker: Mall mean-bred.
sp.p: Yes, that you did, you know what you did, and how you did, and so do I; and gentlefolks as I am a true woman, which he knows I am, I never had more than this white fustian waistcoat, and three pence to buy me three pennyworth of pins, for he would allow me no incle to tie it withal, and this old flannel petticoat, that was his great grandmothers in eighty eight, I am no two-legged creature else.

sp.speaker: Sir gold. Rich.
sp.p: But I bought you velvet to guard it withal.

sp.speaker: Mall mean-bred.
sp.p: Yes, that's true, an old black velvet jerkin without sleeves, that had belonged to one of Queen Elizabeth her learned counsel in the law of blessed memory, primo of her reign, and you bought it of an old broker at Nottingham; and as I am a true Christian woman, if our neighbour butcher could almost few it on, it was so mortified.

sp.speaker: Sir gold. Rich.
sp.p: I bought you shoes, and ribbons to tie them withal.

sp.speaker: Mall mean-bred.
sp.p: Look gentlefolks, a pair of wet-leather shoes, that have given me a cold, and two leather points that he calls ribbons, like a lying false man.

sp.speaker: Sir gold Rich.
sp.p: I am sure I bought you stockings and garters.

sp.speaker: Mall mean-bred.
sp.p: Old doncaster-stockins, that I was fain to wash myself with a little borrowed soap, and they were footed with yellow fustian too, and the garters he talks of were lists of cloth, which a tailor gave me for my new-years-gift, and I cannot choose but grieve to see his unkindness; I gave you satisfaction often, but you never satisfied me, I will take it upon my death.

sp.speaker: Sir gold. Rich.
sp.p: Go Gill Flirt, pack away hence.

sp.speaker: Mall mean-bred.
sp.p: Nay that puts me in mind of the pedlars pack you promised me, and I never had so much bought as that I might whistle for them; but I will follow thee to hell, but I will have something more out of thee than I have had, or else I will make all the town ring of me.

sp.speaker: Sir gold. Rich.
sp.p: Here beadles, take her to the correction-house, Bridewell, and let her be punished.

sp.speaker: Mall mean-bred.
sp.p: Is it so, thou miscreant? well, I thought to be thy bride, and not Bridewell, I never thought it in my conscience.

sp.speaker: Lord title,
sp.p: Pray stay.

div.stage: The lord title whispers to Thom. Purveyor, then turns to Mall Mean-bred.

sp.speaker: Lord title.
sp.p: Mall, although you deceived me, and broke your promise, you I will not only save you from the punishment you were to suffer at the correction-house, but I will give thee a husband here, lusty Thom. Purveyor, to whom, for taking thee to wife, I will give him a lease of fifty pounds a year. Here Tom, take her and go marry her.

sp.speaker: Mall mean-bred.
sp.p: Heaven bless your honour.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Come Mall, let us go wed, for fifty pounds a year is better than thy maidenhead.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
